natural problem:
When the first $50$ counting numbers are arranged in columns, as shown, what is the sum of all of the counting numbers in column $\text E?$ \begin{tabular}{lllll}
A & B & C & D & E\\
1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5\\
10 & 9 & 8 & 7 & 6\\
11 & 12 & 13 & 14 & 15\\
20 & 19 & 18 & 17 & 16\\
. & . & . & . & .\\
. & . & . & . & .\\
. & . & . & . & .
\end{tabular}
natural solution: The numbers in the last row are $50,$ $49,$ $48,$ $47,$ $46,$ so we want to find the sum \[5+6+15+16+\dots+45+46.\] The sum of an arithmetic series is equal to the average of the first and last term, multiplied by the number of terms.

We first add $5+15+25+35+45$ by observing that the mean of these five terms is $25,$ so their sum is $25\cdot5.$ Similarly, the mean of the five terms in the sum $6+16+26+36+46$ is $26,$ so their sum is $26\cdot 5.$ Adding these sums, we find that the original sum is $$25\cdot5+26\cdot 5=(25+26)\cdot5=51\cdot5=\boxed{255}.$$

assumes h0 : "sum_E = (\<Sum>n\<in>{1, 3, 5, 7, 9}. (\<Sum>i\<in>{0..9}. 10 * n + i))"
shows  "sum_E = 255"

 We first add $5+15+25+35+45$ by observing that the mean of these five terms is $25,$ so their sum is $25\cdot5.$ Similarly, the mean of the five terms in the sum $6+16+26+36+46$ is $26,$ so their sum is $26\cdot 5.$ Adding these sums, we find that the original sum is $$25\cdot5+26\cdot 5=(25+26)\cdot5=51\cdot5=\boxed{255}.$$

theorem
fixes sum_E :: nat
assumes h0 : "sum_E = (\<Sum>n\<in>{1, 3, 5, 7, 9}. (\<Sum>i\<in>{0..9}. 10 * n + i))"
shows  "sum_E = 255"

a_0.informal problem: Find the sum of all two-digit numbers that have an odd tens digit. The final answer is 255.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes E :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "E 1 = 5"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n > 1 \<and> n \<le> 10 \<longrightarrow> E n = E (n - 1) + 10 - (2 * (n - 1))"
shows  "(\<Sum>i=1..10. E i) = 255"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the first $50$ counting numbers are arranged in columns, as shown, what is the sum of all of the counting numbers in column $\text E?$ \begin{tabular}{lllll}
A & B & C & D & E\\
1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5\\
10 & 9 & 8 & 7 & 6\\
11 & 12 & 13 & 14 & 15\\
20 & 19 & 18 & 17 & 16\\
. & . & . & . & .\\
. & . & . & . & .\\
. & . & . & . & .
\end{tabular} The final Answer is 255
 ### Proof
 The numbers in the last row are $50,$ $49,$ $48,$ $47,$ $46,$ so we want to find the sum \[5+6+15+16+\dots+45+46.\] The sum of an arithmetic series is equal to the average of the first and last term, multiplied by the number of terms.
 We first add $5+15+25+35+45$ by observing that the mean of these five terms is $25,$ so their sum is $25\cdot5.$ Similarly, the mean of the five terms in the sum $6+16+26+36+46$ is $26,$ so their sum is $26\cdot 5.$ Adding these sums, we find that the original sum is $$25\cdot5+26\cdot 5=(25+26)\cdot5=51\cdot5=\boxed{255}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes E :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "E 1 = 5"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n > 1 \<and> n \<le> 10 \<longrightarrow> E n = E (n - 1) + 10 - (2 * (n - 1))"
shows  "(\<Sum>i=1..10. E i) = 255"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A sequence $E(n)$ is defined as follows: $E(1)=5$, and for $2 \leq n \leq 10$, $E(n) = E(n-1) + 10 - 2(n-1)$. Calculate the sum of the first 10 terms of the sequence. The final answer is $255$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes column_sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> 10 \<longrightarrow> column_sum i = 5 * i + 20 * ((i - 1) div 2)"
shows  "column_sum 5 = 255"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

. & . & . & . & .
\end{tabular} The final Answer is 255
 ### Proof
 The numbers in the last row are $50,$ $49,$ $48,$ $47,$ $46,$ so we want to find the sum \[5+6+15+16+\dots+45+46.\] The sum of an arithmetic series is equal to the average of the first and last term, multiplied by the number of terms.
 We first add $5+15+25+35+45$ by observing that the mean of these five terms is $25,$ so their sum is $25\cdot5.$ Similarly, the mean of the five terms in the sum $6+16+26+36+46$ is $26,$ so their sum is $26\cdot 5.$ Adding these sums, we find that the original sum is $$25\cdot5+26\cdot 5=(25+26)\cdot5=51\cdot5=\boxed{255}.$$

theorem
fixes column_sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> 10 \<longrightarrow> column_sum i = 5 * i + 20 * ((i - 1) div 2)"
shows  "column_sum 5 = 255"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given a function that calculates the sum of a column, defined as $column\_sum(i) = 5i + 20\left(\frac{i-1}{2}\right)$ for all $1 \leq i \leq 10$. Find the value of $column\_sum(5)$. The final answer is 255.

shows  "column_E_sum 4 = 255"
a_3.formal solution:

a_3.informal problem: Find the sum of the numbers in the fifth column of a table, where the sum of the numbers in each column is given by the formula $5 + 6 + 15 + 16 + 10k$, with $k$ ranging from $0$ to $4$. The final answer is $255$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes E :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "E 1 = 5"
and h1 : "E 2 = 6"
and h2 : "E 3 = 15"
and h3 : "E 4 = 16"
and h4 : "\<forall> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 50 \<longrightarrow> (n mod 10 = 5 \<longrightarrow> E n = n) \<or> (n mod 10 = 6 \<longrightarrow> E n = n - 4)"
shows  "sum E {1..50} = 255"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the first $50$ counting numbers are arranged in columns, as shown, what is the sum of all of the counting numbers in column $\text E?$ \begin{tabular}{lllll}
A & B & C & D & E\\
1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5\\
10 & 9 & 8 & 7 & 6\\
11 & 12 & 13 & 14 & 15\\
20 & 19 & 18 & 17 & 16\\
. & . & . & . & .\\
. & . & . & . & .\\
. & . & . & . & .
\end{tabular} The final Answer is 255
 ### Proof
 The numbers in the last row are $50,$ $49,$ $48,$ $47,$ $46,$ so we want to find the sum \[5+6+15+16+\dots+45+46.\] The sum of an arithmetic series is equal to the average of the first and last term, multiplied by the number of terms.
 We first add $5+15+25+35+45$ by observing that the mean of these five terms is $25,$ so their sum is $25\cdot5.$ Similarly, the mean of the five terms in the sum $6+16+26+36+46$ is $26,$ so their sum is $26\cdot 5.$ Adding these sums, we find that the original sum is $$25\cdot5+26\cdot 5=(25+26)\cdot5=51\cdot5=\boxed{255}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes E :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "E 1 = 5"
and h1 : "E 2 = 6"
and h2 : "E 3 = 15"
and h3 : "E 4 = 16"
and h4 : "\<forall> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 50 \<longrightarrow> (n mod 10 = 5 \<longrightarrow> E n = n) \<or> (n mod 10 = 6 \<longrightarrow> E n = n - 4)"
shows  "sum E {1..50} = 255"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem:
Consider a function $E$ defined for natural numbers as follows:

1. $E(1) = 5$
2. $E(2) = 6$
3. $E(3) = 15$
4. $E(4) = 16$
5. For all $n$ in the range $1 \leq n \leq 50$, if $n$ is congruent to $5$ modulo $10$, then $E(n) = n$. If $n$ is congruent to $6$ modulo $10$, then $E(n) = n - 4$.

Find the sum of $E(n)$ for all $n$ in the range $1$ to $50$. The final answer is $255$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sum_E :: "nat => nat"
assumes h0 : "sum_E 1 = 5"
and h1 : "\<forall> n \<ge> 1. sum_E (n + 1) = sum_E n + 10 * n - 4"
shows  "sum_E 50 = 255"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the first $50$ counting numbers are arranged in columns, as shown, what is the sum of all of the counting numbers in column $\text E?$ \begin{tabular}{lllll}
A & B & C & D & E\\
1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5\\
10 & 9 & 8 & 7 & 6\\
11 & 12 & 13 & 14 & 15\\
20 & 19 & 18 & 17 & 16\\
. & . & . & . & .\\
. & . & . & . & .\\
. & . & . & . & .
\end{tabular} The final Answer is 255
 ### Proof
 The numbers in the last row are $50,$ $49,$ $48,$ $47,$ $46,$ so we want to find the sum \[5+6+15+16+\dots+45+46.\] The sum of an arithmetic series is equal to the average of the first and last term, multiplied by the number of terms.
 We first add $5+15+25+35+45$ by observing that the mean of these five terms is $25,$ so their sum is $25\cdot5.$ Similarly, the mean of the five terms in the sum $6+16+26+36+46$ is $26,$ so their sum is $26\cdot 5.$ Adding these sums, we find that the original sum is $$25\cdot5+26\cdot 5=(25+26)\cdot5=51\cdot5=\boxed{255}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes sum_E :: "nat => nat"
assumes h0 : "sum_E 1 = 5"
and h1 : "\<forall> n \<ge> 1. sum_E (n + 1) = sum_E n + 10 * n - 4"
shows  "sum_E 50 = 255"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: A sequence is defined recursively by $E(1)=5$ and $E(n+1)=E(n)+10n-4$ for all integers $n \geq 1$. What is the value of $E(50)$? The final answer is 255.

fixes column_E :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "column_E 1 = 5"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> column_E (n + 1) = column_E n + 10"
shows  "(\<Sum> i = 1..5. column_E i) = 255"

theorem
fixes column_E :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "column_E 1 = 5"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> column_E (n + 1) = column_E n + 10"
shows  "(\<Sum> i = 1..5. column_E i) = 255"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A sequence of numbers is given by the following rule: the first number in the sequence is 5, and each subsequent number is 10 more than the previous number. Find the sum of the first 5 numbers in the sequence. The final answer is 255.
